MOnday, May IA. Prayer by the Rt. Rev. Bishop Brownell. No business Ofimportance was done this af- ternoon; the house being thin, an adjourn ment took place at an early hour. .-. .e {, Tuesday. May 15. Prayer by the Rev. Professor Doane.

 The committee on the petition ofFrederick WoleOtt and others for an act tofincorporation for Female Academy in LitchAeld, reported in favor of granting the same, and bill for this purpose was read.

 An amendment was adopted providing for the alteration, amendment, and a repeal of the act, at the pleasure of the General Assem- bly.-And a motion was made to amend the bill further, by striking ont the 10th section, which exempts the property of the Corpora ton from taxation. After considerable de- bate, this motion was negatived, and the ques- tion recurring on the passage of the bill the House was equally divided: the Speaker vo- ting in the affirmative, the bill passed.

 The committee on the petition of Alva Mead and others, for an act ofincorporation for an Academy at Greenwich reported in favor of the same, and a bill in form for that purpose was read. Mr. Ellsworth mo- we'd to amend the clause exempting the prop erty of the Corporation from taxation. by limiting the term of exemption to three years.

 The committee on the petition of sundry inhabitants of the society of Columbia, in the towns of Cheshire and Waterbury, praying to be incorporated into new to !vn, reported in favor of the same, and bill for this pur- pose was passed. The vote of the Senate negativing the same being read, Messrs. Hitchcock and Hinman were appointed a Committee of Conference.

 The Committee to whom was referred a

come under discussion.--The question of war or peace hangs upon it.

 ST. JOHNS, N. B. April 12.

 We believe the best informed people, even those who have been desirouS of ob- taininp amicable relations between Great Britain and the United States, begin to be somewhat Sceptical on this point. The present misunderstanding between the two countries, on the subjects of the Col onial Trade, and the Boundary Line, to- gether with some other questions which must be agitated between the course ct this and the next year, confirm us Tn the opinion that is both our duty and our ln- terest to be prepared for the worst, while we have an opportunity of endeavorlng to do so.-City Gazette.

 The Editor of tho Democratic Press offers the following as his objections to the election of Gen. Jackson.

 l. His claims and qualifications are wholly Military and founded on Military services his whole life shows that that implicit obedience so essential in soldiers, has been rigourously exacted by him on all occasions but he has not been obedient even in military matters, when orders have been issued from the highest constitution al authority. There is abundant evidence of this truth, in the correspondence of Gen. Jackson with Gen. Scott and Gov. Rabun.

 2.I Gen. Jackson had any quali6ca- tions for Civit life, they mast have been studiously concealed. It is not probable, however, that he has any ,as he has resign ed every Civil Station he ever he'd, from a sense of his own incompetency to dis charge them. How then could the desti- nies of this great and prosperous country be safely deposited in hands so incompetent and inexperienced What crude ideas of Civil Government must that man have who acknowledges candidate for the Presiden- cy, to be " THE BEST OF MEN AND pHE GREATEST CIVILIAN ''yet opposes his election because he''coULD NOT LOOK ON BLOOD AND CARNAGE with any composure. J Yet such were the very words of Gen Jackson, and such his reason for opposing MT. Madison.

 g. He has resigned his station as Senator of the U. States on becoming candidate for the Chief Magistracy, to the end that his principles and course of policy should remain unknown, for fear they shotld give offence. The conseqence is, that his par tizans, in one state present him as friendly to the encouragement of American Manu' factures, and in another, as an enemy tt the Tariff thus in all the various state his partizans are left at liberty to mak' such representations as suit their particn lar districts, and the people are as igno rant of his opinions on great questions c public policy as they are of his politica principles. .s. ~,s-

 \ 4. The public know but little of tn political opinions of Gen. Jackson, an what they do know are in direct hostility one of the most Sacred Rights of Man the right of Suffrage. He was mainly in strumental in grating on the Constitution ( Tennessee the privilege ofa Freeholder vote, and disqualifying all but large Free holders from being members of the Gene ral Assembly.

 ] 5. His total ignorance, and daring viola tions of the first principles of our Govern ment, Constitution and Laws" ] We extact the following from Ne, York paper.

port and accompanying bill were laid on the table.

 A resolution was passed appointing com mittee to enauiire what alterations if any are necessary in the laws regarding foreign at tachments.

 A bill was passed appointing Jeremy HOadly and Solomon Porter directors of the Phoenix Bank on the part Ofthe state.

 The bill for public act relating to the.set clement of estates testate, Intestate, ana In- solvent, which was discussed last week, was taken up, and on motion of MT. Benedict re- ferred to a select committee Ofthree. A bill for a public act providing that in the ] sale of all articles by Avordupos weight 100 lbs. should constitute a cwt. and 20O0 ton, and the aIiauot parts of tie same shall be ! reckoned accordingly. was taken up, and on melton of MT. T. Pitkin, who thought the bill would render some alteration in the general law on weights and measures necessary it was laid on the table.

 The Report of the Agents of the Eagle Bank was taken up, and on motion Ot MT. Kimberly it was referred to a joint committee l of one from county on the part of the | House.

 The Report of the commissioners appoint ed to build the State Prison was read, and ] with accompanying documents referred to l the committee on the State Prison. 1 A resolution appointing committee to take into consideration the expediency of in- creasing the compensation allowed to the publishers of the laws, was introduced by MT. ! Ingersoll and ncgatlved.

 The committee on the petition of Ezra 1 Hunt for release from confinement in New gate prison reported in favor of the same, and bill for this purpose was passed. Wednesday, May 16. Prayer by the Rev. Mir. Sears. Reports ofcommittees on sundry petitions 1 of a private nature were taken up and acted upon. { The report of the committee on the memo rial of the 10th Company Light Artillery in Stonigton stating that they had been or ] selves and done duty accordingly-that fines Company by the Capt. of the Infantry Com pany in that place, that they had appealed to the Capt. General, but that no decision had been had praying to be exonerated from said fines. On this report a discussion occu- pying more than an hour took place-the re- port was finally accepted, and the accompa- nying bill passed.

 The committee on the petition of Truman Starr and others, for an alteration in the char ter of Goshen Academy, reported m favor of the same; report accepted, and accompany ing bill passed. A bill for public act authorizing the Capt.

 General to aher'the limits of Regiments, and transfer companies from one regiment to an

 other, was taken up and passed.

 Several bills for puplic acts received their

 of increasing the compensation allowed tc } the publishers of the laws.

 he was confident the House misapprehendet z the object of tie resolution at that time-i did not propose to establish any specific rule but merely to appoint committee of inquiry - he was informed that the compensation a . present allowed was only about one 1-12tf the amount charged for. ordinary advertise ments-amounting in the whole to about thre. dolars-if such were the fact, he could see nc

 allowed for it-he could see no possible objec ton to appointing committee. 4 A message was received from the Govern or transmitting certain resolutions of the

 or,transmitting certain resolutions ofthe State of Delaware, Connecticut, Illinois, and Ohio

 House in New-Hayen, reported a resolution appropriating S26,OOO towards the erection O a new building, this sum being two-thirds o the estimate expenses of the same.-After 6

 few remarks from Messrs. Boardman and T. n 4 Al. A L-Sl

and John Q. Wilson, Esqs. committee tO superintend the building the same. Report No. 2, of Committee on military affairs was read and accepted.

 The report of the committee on so much of the Governors message as relates to dis ticiing was read together with certain resO- luti0ns reported by them, as amendments to the COnstitutiOn-These resolutions provide that from the first Wednesday of May 1880, the Senate shall consist ofno less than 1 nor mere than 24 members. That in May 1929, the State shall be divided into no more than l8 nor less than districts-each district to be formed of contiguous territory--whch district shall not be altered oftner than once in ten years. On motion the resolutions and prepOrt were laid on the table, and $50 copies ordered to be printed. On motion of Mir. Benedict these reselu- tions were made the order of the day for Tuesday morning next. An act concerning crimes and punishments was read third time and negatived. A bill appointing Justices of the Peace, for Middlesex County was rad and passed. The report of the committee on petitions of Asahel Miller, who was wounded while per- forming military duty, was read and accepted, and his petition granted, so far as to pay him 1 $200.

 | A resolution from the Senate to ircorpo-

  l Masons, with liberty to hold property prodn- cling an annual income of SSOOO, was read, l andafter some discussion, ordered to lie on l the table.

 The committee on new towns reported a gainst granting the petition of k. Hickock and others-report accepted. 1 A bill for an act to authorize the sale of personal property in certain cases, was read a second time, and after some debate, was referred to select committee.

 At the annual meeting of the Conecticut Medical Society, legally convened at the State House in Hartford, May 9th 1927.

 Thomas Hubbard M. D. the President of the Society, having declined reelection. ELI TODD, NT. D. was elected President

 The society received communications from Drs. Samuel l.. Mitchell, David HOsack, of

 ton,and T. R. Beck, of Albany, acknowledging

 Communicates were received from scv- eral medical societies and colleges on the Z subject of medical education SIC. The society [ approved of the object of these communica-- tions, and appointed Samuel B. Woodward, M. D. and G Sumner, Nj. D. Delegates to the Meeting at Northampton on the eOth of June Z next. which was manlieStly increased by pota- tions of ardent spirits. The next day he wandered about the town, appeared ap- prehensive that he was pursued, and was last seen entering piece of woods above the bend of the Connecticut. On Sum day last, his body was found in ravine which had been filled water few days be- fore, by the rise of the river. A jury of inquest was summoned, and their verdict was, that he came to his death by drown- ing while in a state of mental derange- ment, produced by incorporate drinking His name, we understand, was Joseph Richards, and he had resided at Concord, in this State.

 Lime necessary for peGs.-It is observ- ed, that the common pea, whether white or gray, cannot be reared to perfection in any field which has not been either natur- ally or arti6cially inprcgnated with some calc0reous matter. And hence it is supp posed to happen, that peas are rarely cnl- tivated universally as field crop, unless in those parts of the country where either lime, mari or chalk abounds, or upon strong clays; except, indeed, on the sea coast, where shell-ish are often catched in abundance, and where the fields are n,anured with their shells in state of mixture with dung. But it is remarkable, that soil that could scarcely have brought one pea to perfection, although richly manured with dung, from their running too much to haulm, and after blessoming, dying away without becoming ripe, if it has once lime applied upon it, is capable, when properly prepared in other resp ects, of producing plentiful crops of peas ever afterwards. It is further remarked by the same writer, on the result of an ex- pertinent, in which the ridge of field had been missed in lining, produced no wheat, while all the other parts afforded full crop, that lime or some calcareous mate- rial is equally necessary for the production of good wheat crops, as for those of the pea kind. The general observation that the wheat, where this sort of manure has been employed, is thinner in the skin, more plump and yields better, seems also to favour the same conclusion. Im- preparations of this sort appear, likewise, it is supposed, particularly favourable for the production of barley crops, much more SO, especially if in large proportions, than for those of oats.-Farmer's CompDnien.

 1he preservation of teeth.-It is the concern of each individual to cherish and improve his own physical system-as it is the province to repair and restore this whenever it is injured by accident or im- paired by disease. These respective off, ces, though they often more or less run in each other, are instances quite distinct as in the management of the teeth. Tbe possessor has merely to keep the teett clean this being all that is requisite fol their preservation the dentist must dc the rest.

 This keeping the teeth free from impu' rites is indispensable to their soundnes' and good appearance. To suffer tho

 particles of food and other offending ma

 terials, which are constantly collecting a

 bout them, to remain, is to favo UT the pro

 duction and activity of those causes whicl

 effect their ruin. Whatever, therefore, i

 best suited to keep these instruments clean, is also best suited to prevent thei discoloration and decay. Whoever is ac' customed to the luxury of clean mouth and teeth, feels the want of his refresh ment as strongly, and enjoys it as highly as ba,her does pure skin.

 We every day meet with reputable peo. pie who mean to be neat, and have the satisfaction ofimagining they are so, ant yet they neither bathe the skin nor rins

 the mouth Their standard of physica

 purity must be very low, for how can neat ness consist with neglected surface and mouth Some young persons, who arc pleasing and estimable in other respects seem to have no idea of tho unpleasant effect which the sordid state of their teeth must have on their acquaintance and asso. ciatss. To see the bloom and freshness Oi youth, in connection with yellow and GOV. einred teeth, and an offensive breath, are altogether from total neglect of the mouth, is grossly inccngruous, if not dis gusting.' Common sense on the contrary, with good manners, and proper attention to personal cleanliness, makes one current and acceptable every where.-Boston Med. InN.

 The Baltimore Weekly Register, says, The American people will accept of no other arrangement with England, on the score of the Colonial Intercourse. than

*The appearance of our squadron in the Archipelago, impressed upon the people a high idea of our navy. The Greeks speak in raptures of the North Carolina. Some of the old Hydriote sailors, speaking of her, said, "we never knew what a ship was, before we went on board of her, and we have seen the ships of every nation in the world" Whatey yer may have been the policy of the government, in sending so large force up the Mediterranean, it has had at least the effect to heighten the reputation of our county in Eu-' rope. see much of the naval officers of all nations, and can say that where our officers are best known, they are most esteemed. remember, the other day,to have heard some British officers say, Well to tell the truth and shame the devil, I see nothing in the Yankee ships or men, inferior to ours. Then they are really gentlemen Strange as it may appear if Ishad not known them to be Jonathans, should have taken them for John Bulls !''

We are informed that few days since, in this village, scene was acted at the re- cital of which Credulity herself might look doubtful. A man afflicted with disease of the lungs, ofsome standing, applied to one of the high pressure fraternity, alias {" Thompson Doctors," for relief.-The physician, to restore order between the two contending principles which seem to be at the bottom of all the sqabbles, with. in us, viz. internal and external heat, anc give the due preponderance to the former determined that his patient should inhale the fumes of burning sulphur.-This, by the bye, we hold to be an improvement, even of patent dOctering" and one that is original with our modern Esculapius. We would suggest, however, the more direct method of thrusting the lighted birthstone match down the invalid's neck for then we should more directly come into the aid of the said internal heat-reinforcing and enabling it to overcome its wicked adyer- sary. The sick man's relations assembled to witness. and assist in the application oi the remedy. The patieut was seated on the floor, the sulphur was ignited-a bed covering thrown over him and four stout men selected to hold it there given num- Der of minutes; the patients struggling (for he could not squeaD to tho contary notwithstanding But his wife seeing her ''better half'' kicking so lustily, and man. ifesting SO much dissatisfaction with his sit- uation, began at once to apply both her tongue and hands to his rescue-by which means she saved his life but prevented the cure of his malady, to the no small re- gret of the Doctor and the perfect ap- probation of the sufferer who as soon as he could speak, declared he would rather have the asthma than be cured in tn at manner;' and dobtless had in his minds eye an improvement of Shakespeare, thus 'sThrow birthstone to the dogs.I' none of it!' Query,-Should we most detest the im- postar, or commiserate the fools imposed ou2

Hartford APrI z.

 A mercantile friend in this town has per- ,nitted us to make the following extract from letter of his correspondent, (Coro, Republic of Columbia, South America. ! April 2d, 1927. cannot say any thing fattering to you---this country has been in continual uproar since Bolivar made his appearance. His decrees, refusing to receive government paper at the Custom House, and an additional duty of 40 per cent on importations have almost stopped all business. Merchants have re- fused to pay their duties in cash which Ina. been demanded, in consequence of whicf a number have been taken to jail. The American, English and Dutch Consul. hsye taken the matter up, and are making a government business ofit.-Mirror.

 NORTHAMPTON, (Mass.) May 9. 4a On Caft1Fdov Nr;l % {, su,aIl ].osso<

The Philadelphia Gazette is of an opin- ion that our differences with G. Britain on the subject of the Colonial trade will have an important effect on the general policy ofthe two nations in relation to va-

vier, 30,OOO francs per month The con- duet of the Frenh people towards Greece, has been really noble and generous nel- ther have tho Germans nor Swiss been behind. The safety of the country now' as in the days of Themistocles, lies in her wooden walls. Mistress upon the sea, she is secure upon the continent. his leads me to mention the arrival ofthe trig- ate built in America, and which has diff fused ioy among the Greeks. learn that Miaulis has gone on board and taken her to Epina, where the National Assembly is now sitting. How she will be disposed of, know not yet the general wish is, that she may be commanded and manned by Americans*-but this seems hardly probable. Government have received let- ters from Cochrane, dated MarseIlIes, where he is making arrangements with the European committees, for the purchase oi a large corvette of g guns, built for the Paclla of Egypt, but which he has not the means of paying for. Lord Cochrane'S Expedition is the sheet-anchor of Greece, and hope brightens into certainty. Some- thing will be done in the Spring the Greeks have already two of the most powerful vessels that swim, in their ser- vice: I speak of this one, and the GA gun ship. More will probably arrive this win- ter and if they have been able, with their little fleet of merchant brigs, to meet with the Turkish line of battle-ships, what may not be hoped from an equal force.-Give us the sea, and Turkey may pour in upon us as many hordes as ever did Persia, and Greece will be as little harmed by them.

 In my next hope to give you an ac- count of the operations of the National Assembly, which have just convened at Egina.

 Meanwhile, remain yours sincerely,

 S.. HOWE.
NORTHAMPTON, (Mass.) May 9. On Saturday, April 28, well dressed

Rhode-Island.--Tne Legislature of Rhode-Island met on "Wednesday last, at Newport, to hold three days session. During this brief session, the Providence Journal says, all the officers of the State, civil and military, from the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court down to ensigns of the militia companies, are appointed.

 It has been usual on this occasion for the Governor to treat the citizens, but Governor Fenner this year omitted doing it, and gave hundred dollars (,hat being about the sum which collation. would have cost)to the school committee of New. port, toward the support of the free school in that place. The example was initiated by It. Gov. Collins, who gave fifty dol- lars for the. same object. Gov. fenner says he was induced in part to make this donation by the consideration that on these occasions some of the people indulge to excess in drinking, and he. wished to show his disapprobation of intemperance, and to assist in preventing it.-[solsm Goz.l

The Baltimore Weekly Register, says, The American people will accept of no other arrangement with England, on the score of the Colonial Intercourse, than that ofreciprocity. They will maintain the old ground supported by MT. Jeff ferson, when Secretary of State in 1791, and by every administration since, (except as partially 'oaived by what is called ''Jay's treaty." because of peculiar circumstances) which have not latterally existed and can- not be admitted. Whatever of "free trade" Great-Britain will yield to US we will grant unto her {: but we shall more and more press reciprocity upon her, or retire from her monopolies. The time will come when, if Britain will not receive our -four, we shall exclude her cloths. This pro- ceeding is due to the independence of our country--and the farmers will command it."
rious other points which must shortly come under discussion.--The question of war or peace hangs upon it.

 The Report of the Agents of the Eagle Bank was taken up, and on motion Ot MT. Kimberly it was referred to a joint committee l of one from county on the part of the | House.

 The Report of the commissioners appoint ed to build the State Prison was read, and ] with accompanying documents referred to l the committee on the State Prison. 1 A resolution appointing committee to take into consideration the expediency of in- creasing the compensation allowed to the publishers of the laws, was introduced by MT. ! Ingersoll and ncgatlved.

 The committee on the petition of Ezra 1 Hunt for release from confinement in New gate prison reported in favor of the same, and bill for this purpose was passed. Wednesday, May 16. Prayer by the Rev. Mir. Sears. Reports ofcommittees on sundry petitions 1 of a private nature were taken up and acted upon. { The report of the committee on the memo rial of the 10th Company Light Artillery in Stonigton stating that they had been or ] selves and done duty accordingly-that fines Company by the Capt. of the Infantry Com pany in that place, that they had appealed to the Capt. General, but that no decision had been had praying to be exonerated from said fines. On this report a discussion occu- pying more than an hour took place-the re- port was finally accepted, and the accompa- nying bill passed.

 The committee on the petition of Truman Starr and others, for an alteration in the char ter of Goshen Academy, reported m favor of the same; report accepted, and accompany ing bill passed. A bill for public act authorizing the Capt.

 thought objectionable, the House could re ject it.

 Mir. Shepherd thought that the honor o

 the State required that they should at least ap point committee he understood the mat f ter was now regulated by the Comptroller |, the bills were handed to him blank to be fill r ed up according to his discretion, the sum Il - sually paid was very small; if it was prope that the laws should be printed, it is certainl, proper that a suitable compensation should b.

 allowed for it-he could see no possible objec ton to appointing committee. 4 A message was received from the Govern or transmitting certain resolutions of the

 State of Georgia, which was referred to ti1t committee on the resolutions from Maine.

 A message was received from the Govern

 or,transmitting certain resolutions ofthe State of Delaware, Connecticut, Illinois, and Ohio

 ernor, transmitting certain resolutions ofVer,

 House in New-Hayen, reported a resolution appropriating S26,OOO towards the erection O a new building, this sum being two-thirds o the estimate expenses of the same.-After 6

 few remarks from Messrs. Boardman and T. n 4 Al. A L-Sl

and John Q. Wilson, Esqs. committee tO superintend the building the same. Report No. 2, of Committee on military affairs was read and accepted.

 The report of the committee on so much of the Governors message as relates to dis ticiing was read together with certain resO- luti0ns reported by them, as amendments to the COnstitutiOn-These resolutions provide that from the first Wednesday of May 1880, the Senate shall consist ofno less than 1 nor mere than 24 members. That in May 1929, the State shall be divided into no more than l8 nor less than districts-each district to be formed of contiguous territory--whch district shall not be altered oftner than once in ten years. On motion the resolutions and prepOrt were laid on the table, and $50 copies ordered to be printed. On motion of Mir. Benedict these reselu- tions were made the order of the day for Tuesday morning next. An act concerning crimes and punishments was read third time and negatived. A bill appointing Justices of the Peace, for Middlesex County was rad and passed. The report of the committee on petitions of Asahel Miller, who was wounded while per- forming military duty, was read and accepted, and his petition granted, so far as to pay him 1 $200.

 | A resolution from the Senate to ircorpo-

  l Masons, with liberty to hold property prodn- cling an annual income of SSOOO, was read, l andafter some discussion, ordered to lie on l the table.

 The committee on new towns reported a gainst granting the petition of k. Hickock and others-report accepted. 1 A bill for an act to authorize the sale of personal property in certain cases, was read a second time, and after some debate, was referred to select committee.

The society [ approved of the object of these communica-- tions, and appointed Samuel B. Woodward, M. D. and G Sumner, Nj. D. Delegates to the Meeting at Northampton on the eOth of June Z next. which was manlieStly increased by pota- tions of ardent spirits. The next day he wandered about the town, appeared ap- prehensive that he was pursued, and was last seen entering piece of woods above the bend of the Connecticut. On Sum day last, his body was found in ravine which had been filled water few days be- fore, by the rise of the river. A jury of inquest was summoned, and their verdict was, that he came to his death by drown- ing while in a state of mental derange- ment, produced by incorporate drinking His name, we understand, was Joseph Richards, and he had resided at Concord, in this State.

 Lime necessary for peGs.-It is observ- ed, that the common pea, whether white or gray, cannot be reared to perfection in any field which has not been either natur- ally or arti6cially inprcgnated with some calc0reous matter. And hence it is supp posed to happen, that peas are rarely cnl- tivated universally as field crop, unless in those parts of the country where either lime, mari or chalk abounds, or upon strong clays; except, indeed, on the sea coast, where shell-ish are often catched in abundance, and where the fields are n,anured with their shells in state of mixture with dung. But it is remarkable, that soil that could scarcely have brought one pea to perfection, although richly manured with dung, from their running too much to haulm, and after blessoming, dying away without becoming ripe, if it has once lime applied upon it, is capable, when properly prepared in other resp ects, of producing plentiful crops of peas ever afterwards. It is further remarked by the same writer, on the result of an ex- pertinent, in which the ridge of field had been missed in lining, produced no wheat, while all the other parts afforded full crop, that lime or some calcareous mate- rial is equally necessary for the production of good wheat crops, as for those of the pea kind. The general observation that the wheat, where this sort of manure has been employed, is thinner in the skin, more plump and yields better, seems also to favour the same conclusion. Im- preparations of this sort appear, likewise, it is supposed, particularly favourable for the production of barley crops, much more SO, especially if in large proportions, than for those of oats.-Farmer's CompDnien.

 1he preservation of teeth.-It is the concern of each individual to cherish and improve his own physical system-as it is the province to repair and restore this whenever it is injured by accident or im- paired by disease. These respective off, ces, though they often more or less run in each other, are instances quite distinct as in the management of the teeth. Tbe possessor has merely to keep the teett clean this being all that is requisite fol their preservation the dentist must dc the rest.

 This keeping the teeth free from impu' rites is indispensable to their soundnes' and good appearance. To suffer tho

 particles of food and other offending ma

 terials, which are constantly collecting a

 bout them, to remain, is to favo UT the pro

 duction and activity of those causes whicl

 effect their ruin. Whatever, therefore, i

 best suited to keep these instruments clean, is also best suited to prevent thei discoloration and decay. Whoever is ac' customed to the luxury of clean mouth and teeth, feels the want of his refresh ment as strongly, and enjoys it as highly as ba,her does pure skin.

 We every day meet with reputable peo. pie who mean to be neat, and have the satisfaction ofimagining they are so, ant yet they neither bathe the skin nor rins

 the mouth Their standard of physica

 purity must be very low, for how can neat ness consist with neglected surface and mouth Some young persons, who arc pleasing and estimable in other respects seem to have no idea of tho unpleasant effect which the sordid state of their teeth must have on their acquaintance and asso. ciatss. To see the bloom and freshness Oi youth, in connection with yellow and GOV. einred teeth, and an offensive breath, are altogether from total neglect of the mouth, is grossly inccngruous, if not dis gusting.' Common sense on the contrary, with good manners, and proper attention to personal cleanliness, makes one current and acceptable every where.-Boston Med. InN.

 The Baltimore Weekly Register, says, The American people will accept of no other arrangement with England, on the score of the Colonial Intercourse. than

*The appearance of our squadron in the Archipelago, impressed upon the people a high idea of our navy. The Greeks speak in raptures of the North Carolina. Some of the old Hydriote sailors, speaking of her, said, "we never knew what a ship was, before we went on board of her, and we have seen the ships of every nation in the world" Whatey yer may have been the policy of the government, in sending so large force up the Mediterranean, it has had at least the effect to heighten the reputation of our county in Eu-' rope. see much of the naval officers of all nations, and can say that where our officers are best known, they are most esteemed. remember, the other day,to have heard some British officers say, Well to tell the truth and shame the devil, I see nothing in the Yankee ships or men, inferior to ours. Then they are really gentlemen Strange as it may appear if Ishad not known them to be Jonathans, should have taken them for John Bulls !''

full articles.headline: OGDENsBUGH, MAY 1, THOMSONIANISM M.
full articles.article: We are informed that few days since, in this village, scene was acted at the re- cital of which Credulity herself might look doubtful. A man afflicted with disease of the lungs, ofsome standing, applied to one of the high pressure fraternity, alias {" Thompson Doctors," for relief.-The physician, to restore order between the two contending principles which seem to be at the bottom of all the sqabbles, with. in us, viz. internal and external heat, anc give the due preponderance to the former determined that his patient should inhale the fumes of burning sulphur.-This, by the bye, we hold to be an improvement, even of patent dOctering" and one that is original with our modern Esculapius. We would suggest, however, the more direct method of thrusting the lighted birthstone match down the invalid's neck for then we should more directly come into the aid of the said internal heat-reinforcing and enabling it to overcome its wicked adyer- sary. The sick man's relations assembled to witness. and assist in the application oi the remedy. The patieut was seated on the floor, the sulphur was ignited-a bed covering thrown over him and four stout men selected to hold it there given num- Der of minutes; the patients struggling (for he could not squeaD to tho contary notwithstanding But his wife seeing her ''better half'' kicking so lustily, and man. ifesting SO much dissatisfaction with his sit- uation, began at once to apply both her tongue and hands to his rescue-by which means she saved his life but prevented the cure of his malady, to the no small re- gret of the Doctor and the perfect ap- probation of the sufferer who as soon as he could speak, declared he would rather have the asthma than be cured in tn at manner;' and dobtless had in his minds eye an improvement of Shakespeare, thus 'sThrow birthstone to the dogs.I' none of it!' Query,-Should we most detest the im- postar, or commiserate the fools imposed ou2

Hartford APrI z.

 A mercantile friend in this town has per- ,nitted us to make the following extract from letter of his correspondent, (Coro, Republic of Columbia, South America. ! April 2d, 1927. cannot say any thing fattering to you---this country has been in continual uproar since Bolivar made his appearance. His decrees, refusing to receive government paper at the Custom House, and an additional duty of 40 per cent on importations have almost stopped all business. Merchants have re- fused to pay their duties in cash which Ina. been demanded, in consequence of whicf a number have been taken to jail. The American, English and Dutch Consul. hsye taken the matter up, and are making a government business ofit.-Mirror.

 NORTHAMPTON, (Mass.) May 9. 4a On Caft1Fdov Nr;l % {, su,aIl ].osso<

The Philadelphia Gazette is of an opin- ion that our differences with G. Britain on the subject of the Colonial trade will have an important effect on the general policy ofthe two nations in relation to va-

vier, 30,OOO francs per month The con- duet of the Frenh people towards Greece, has been really noble and generous nel- ther have tho Germans nor Swiss been behind. The safety of the country now' as in the days of Themistocles, lies in her wooden walls. Mistress upon the sea, she is secure upon the continent. his leads me to mention the arrival ofthe trig- ate built in America, and which has diff fused ioy among the Greeks. learn that Miaulis has gone on board and taken her to Epina, where the National Assembly is now sitting. How she will be disposed of, know not yet the general wish is, that she may be commanded and manned by Americans*-but this seems hardly probable. Government have received let- ters from Cochrane, dated MarseIlIes, where he is making arrangements with the European committees, for the purchase oi a large corvette of g guns, built for the Paclla of Egypt, but which he has not the means of paying for. Lord Cochrane'S Expedition is the sheet-anchor of Greece, and hope brightens into certainty. Some- thing will be done in the Spring the Greeks have already two of the most powerful vessels that swim, in their ser- vice: I speak of this one, and the GA gun ship. More will probably arrive this win- ter and if they have been able, with their little fleet of merchant brigs, to meet with the Turkish line of battle-ships, what may not be hoped from an equal force.-Give us the sea, and Turkey may pour in upon us as many hordes as ever did Persia, and Greece will be as little harmed by them.

 In my next hope to give you an ac- count of the operations of the National Assembly, which have just convened at Egina.

 Meanwhile, remain yours sincerely,

 S.. HOWE.
NORTHAMPTON, (Mass.) May 9. On Saturday, April 28, well dressed

Rhode-Island.--Tne Legislature of Rhode-Island met on "Wednesday last, at Newport, to hold three days session. During this brief session, the Providence Journal says, all the officers of the State, civil and military, from the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court down to ensigns of the militia companies, are appointed.

 It has been usual on this occasion for the Governor to treat the citizens, but Governor Fenner this year omitted doing it, and gave hundred dollars (,hat being about the sum which collation. would have cost)to the school committee of New. port, toward the support of the free school in that place. The example was initiated by It. Gov. Collins, who gave fifty dol- lars for the. same object. Gov. fenner says he was induced in part to make this donation by the consideration that on these occasions some of the people indulge to excess in drinking, and he. wished to show his disapprobation of intemperance, and to assist in preventing it.-[solsm Goz.l

The Baltimore Weekly Register, says, The American people will accept of no other arrangement with England, on the score of the Colonial Intercourse, than that ofreciprocity. They will maintain the old ground supported by MT. Jeff ferson, when Secretary of State in 1791, and by every administration since, (except as partially 'oaived by what is called ''Jay's treaty." because of peculiar circumstances) which have not latterally existed and can- not be admitted. Whatever of "free trade" Great-Britain will yield to US we will grant unto her {: but we shall more and more press reciprocity upon her, or retire from her monopolies. The time will come when, if Britain will not receive our -four, we shall exclude her cloths. This pro- ceeding is due to the independence of our country--and the farmers will command it."
rious other points which must shortly come under discussion.--The question of war or peace hangs upon it.
